This report was prepared by Diwesh Sharan, Economist, Pacific Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  An economic report for the Fiji Islands under the Pacific Islands Economic Report (PIER) 
series of Asian Development Bank (ADB) was published in 1999. Since then, there have been 
significant changes in the Fiji Islands economy due to the political developments in May 2000. 
Additionally, the global economy has undergone major changes. In June 2002, the Government 
confirmed  its  willingness  to  undertake  a  thorough  study  of  the  economy  with  technical 
assistance (TA) from ADB, which would lead to preparation of a new economic report for the 
country.1 Following the Government's confirmation, the Fact-Finding Mission was fielded from 7 
to 12 September 2002. It reached an understanding with the Government on the objective, 
scope, implementation, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA. The TA 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The main challenge facing the Fiji Islands is to move to a higher growth path, and 
improve the income and quality of life of its people. Despite good potential, the Fiji Islands’ 
average annual economic growth rate has been below 1.5% since the mid-1970s. The factors 
that  caused  lower  economic  growth  include  political  instability,  weak  governance,  and 
uncertainty over property rights. During this period, the structure of the economy also changed 
gradually with the emergence of garments as a major merchandise export, a decline in the 
share of agriculture in total output, and further increases in the share of tourism in total foreign 
exchange earnings. The economy continues to change in response to internal and external 
developments. 
 
3.  The country witnessed a general economic slowdown in 2000 following the crisis in May 
2000, which was associated with a decline in tourist arrivals, and a decline in sugar and 
garments production. There has been a regular out migration of skilled workers since then.  The 
external  environment  also  remained  generally  uncertain  over  this  period.  Despite  these 
difficulties, the management of the Fijian economy since the crisis in May 2000 has been 
commendable as reflected in a broad-based economic recovery in 2002.  
 
4.  The Government is currently pursuing a policy to move the economy to a higher growth 
path through increase in the level of investments. The government priorities include increases in 
public investment, restructuring of the sugar industry, improvement of tourism infrastructure, 
commercial  exploitation  of  the  maturing  mahogany,  catalyzing  of  private  investments  and 
reversal of its declining trend for more than two decades, and support to small and micro 
enterprise  development.  Increases  in  public  investment  have  raised  the  issue  of  fiscal 
sustainability and highlighted the need for urgent reduction in the operating expenditure. Apart 
from sugar, tourism and fisheries have been two major drivers of the economy. In view of the 
numerous difficulties and long-term prospect of losing preferential access to European markets 
for the sugar industry, the Government is also exploring new productive opportunities and 
considering the potential for crop diversification.2  
 
5.  The Government has prepared a detailed agenda for the future development of the 
country, as reflected in the newly drafted document Rebuilding Confidence for Stability and 
Growth for a Peaceful and Prosperous Fiji: 2003-2005. The document was discussed in the

initiated a comprehensive public sector reform in 1990s. This led to adoption of acts related to

lack of clarity, and capacity constraints. The current Government has decided to review the 
Public Finance Management Act 1999.   
 
6.  Through the proposed study of the Fijian economy, the TA will support economic growth, 
public sector reform, private sector development, and poverty reduction, which is in line with the 
regional and country strategy.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.        Purpose and Output  
 
7.  The purpose of the TA is to undertake a comprehensive study and prepare an economic 
report (PIER). The study will review the Fiji Islands' past economic development trends, current 
issues covering relevant sectoral and thematic areas to identify development opportunities, and 
constraints and policy options, and will provide a timely assessment of the economy and its 
major  sectors  for  future  development  prospects.  The  PIER,  therefore,  will  contribute  to 
macroeconomic management, and development policy formulation. It will also provide inputs for 
preparing a country strategy and program (CSP). In addition, the TA will support preparation of 
relevant sector road maps, including for tourism and fisheries. 
 
8.  The TA will provide published information on key constraints and opportunities of the 
economy. Furthermore, the TA will follow a participatory approach in preparing the PIER. Thus it 
will improve awareness of government officials, private sector, and civil society about current 
economic issues and prospects of the economy.  
 
B.        Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The  TA  team  will  work  closely  with  the  Government  to  enhance  feedback, 
understanding,  and  ownership.  The  team  will  also  seek  a  range  of  views  from  other  key 
stakeholders, including private business and civil-society groups. The approach to this study will 
involve consultations, workshops, and seminars, which will also help disseminate information 
within the country while the PIER is being prepared. Special briefing sessions/seminars will be 
organized for senior officials and ministers. The report will be widely distributed as part of ADB’s 
Pacific Studies Series.   
 
10.  The TA will review and analyze the macroeconomic performance of the country in the 
recent past with a view to capturing the underlying trends and future prospects. It will review and 
analyze the major sectors of the economy to identify development opportunities, constraints, 
and policy options. This will include analysis and projection of future scenarios in key sectoral 
and thematic areas. Special attention will be paid to the long-term problems, new challenges, 
and sectors offering new opportunities. Thus, the TA will (i) systematize the past experience and 
studies into a coherent and integrated framework; (ii) update the economic assessment; (iii) 
suggest  further  policy  directions  and  reforms;  and  (iv)  result  in  publication  of  a  new 
comprehensive economic report, which will serve as a major reference document for all the 
stakeholders.

3 
C.        Cost and Financing  
 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $360,000 equivalent, of which $235,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $125,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. ADB will finance an 
amount  equivalent  to  $250,000,  covering  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $15,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The Government will finance the remaining cost of $110,000 equivalent to 
cover the local currency costs related to counterpart staff, office space for the consultants, and 
other local support. The cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.         Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The Ministry of Finance and National Planning will be the Executing Agency for the TA. 
ADB will provide about 7.25 person-months of international consulting services, including a 
macroeconomist,  a  private  sector  development  economist,  an  infrastructure  economist,  an 
agriculture  and  resource  economist,  and  a  social  sector  and  environment  specialist.  The 
macroeconomist will be the team leader and provide intellectual leadership and guidance to the 
team. The team leader will be responsible for the overall quality of the economic report. The 
Government will provide counterpart staff and office space within the Ministry of Finance and 
National Planning, and other support and facilities. The counterpart staff will be actively involved 
in the technical review and analysis to ensure continuity of the Government’s knowledge and 
skills in implementing the TA recommendations. 
 
13.  The  team  leader  will  undertake  the  macroeconomic  parts  of  the  report  and  be 
responsible  for  overall  coordination  and  compilation  of  the  output  of  all  consultants,  and 
preparation of the PIER. The team leader will be engaged for about 2.5 person-months. The 
other three members of the team of consultants will be engaged for about 4–6 person-weeks 
each. They will be responsible for analyzing and preparing reports on sector and thematic 
areas. All the team members will start field work concurrently. Except for the team leader, all 
other consultants will complete most of their work in the field in one stretch and provide their 
draft reports to the team leader. The team leader will finalize the report and assist in its 
publication. Other members of the team of consultants will assist the team leader to accomplish 
these tasks. ADB will also engage an editor to assist the publication of the report. The outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
14.  The TA will commence in January 2003 and be implemented over a period of about 12 
months, with completion expected by January 2004. An international consulting firm will be 
engaged  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Further, the simplified technical proposal procedure will 
apply.  Materials  and  equipment  for  the  TA  will  be  purchased  by  ADB  or  a  consultant,  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement and arrangements acceptable to ADB. TA 
implementation will be monitored and reviewed by ADB missions and regular communications 
with the Ministry of Finance and National Planning and other concerned agencies. 
 
15.  The PIER’s main audience will be government officials and staff of funding and aid 
agencies.  The  business  community,  academics,  students,  and  others  interested  in  the 
development of the Fiji Islands will also use the report. Prominent among these (including 
libraries) will be sent complimentary copies of the PIER by mail.3 In addition, the PIER will be

distributed in selected ADB-related meetings to be held in the near future. The PIER will also be 
sold as an ADB publication.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Fiji Islands for Supporting Economic Management and Development 
Policies, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  team  will  draw  on  existing  material,  including  reports  prepared  by  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  Government,  other  aid  agencies,  and  academicians.  The 
descriptive parts should be brief, and major effort should be placed on the analytical aspects 
and operationally relevant issues. The report should come up with concrete policy advice and 
operationally relevant suggestions. The team will follow a participatory approach by organizing a 
series  of  workshops  and  seminars  involving  all  key  stakeholders.  The  team  should  also 
organize special briefing sessions for senior officials and ministers of the Government before 
leaving the field, near the completion of the basic draft of the Pacific islands economic report 
(PIER) for the Fiji Islands. The macroeconomist will be the team leader, provide the team with 
intellectual leadership and guidance, and be responsible for the overall quality of the economic 
report. Together, the team will prepare a comprehensive and complete report covering all 
important aspects and identifying the key development challenges. As far as possible, the team 
will compare their findings with the lessons from other Pacific island and Caribbean countries to 
bring out new issues and suggest new directions, as appropriate. The team will also prepare 
relevant sector road maps, including for fisheries and tourism. Since the PIER is expected to 
serve as a major reference document, it should contain detailed statistical tables and data on 
relevant items.  
A.  Macroeconomist―Team Leader (2.5 person-months) 
 
2.  The terms of reference (TOR) of the team leader will include but not be limited to the 
following: 
 
(i)  Briefly  review  and  analyze  significant  overall  historic  trends  in  the  country’s 
macroeconomic  development,  including  all  major  macroeconomic  aggregates 
(including  national  accounts  aggregates,  inflation,  etc.),  and  changes  in  the 
structure of economy and external transactions. Review and analyze in detail the 
period after the last PIER for the Fiji Islands. 
(ii)  Assess  and  suggest  improvement  in  the  Government’s  fiscal  policy,  fiscal 
performance, budgeting and planning frameworks, integration of planning and 
budgeting processes, and allocations for different items. Draw a comparison with 
other countries regarding allocations for different items. Analyze the sustainability 
aspect of budget deficit and public debt. 
(iii)  Review the progress and status of economic, public sector, and governance 
reforms,  and  suggest  priorities  in  view  of  the  recent  domestic  and  external 
developments.   
(iv)  Review  and  analyze  the  balance-of-payments  account  and  its  components, 
monetary policy, exchange rate regime, exchange control and capital movements 
with a view to improving the effectiveness of the policies in maintaining economic 
growth with macroeconomic stability. 
(v)  Review and analyze trade policy and impact of preferential trade agreements. 
Construct various scenarios building on assumptions of withdrawal of preferential 
agreements. Suggest improvements and policy directions. 
(vi)  Examine  the  role  of  commercial  public  enterprises,  including  their  financial 
management,  and  comment  on  policies  and  strategies  to  improve  their 
effectiveness and efficiency, and sequencing of reforms.  
(vii)  Analyze the likely impact in investment level and its sustainability due to increase 
in the Government's capital expenditure. Make concrete suggestions about the

Appendix 3  9 
newly formed the Fiji Investment Corporation, and examine the possibility of 
establishing venture capital funds in the country. 
(viii)  Review the employment trends, labor market conditions, impact of out-migration 
of skilled labor, and wage policy, giving special consideration to their gender 
aspects. Review and analyze the price controls administered in the country.  
(ix)  Review and analyze the impact of governance issues on economic efficiency, 
economic  development,  and  investments.  Identify  areas  that  need  to  be 
strengthened. 
(x)  Examine  the  land  tenure  system,  and  identify  constraints  to  economic 
development caused by these. Suggest acceptable reforms.  
(xi)  Review  and  analyze  the  status  and  performance  of  the  financial  sector,  its 
outreach to rural areas, and costs of capital, including competition and regulation 
issues.  Comment on the National Provident Fund (NPF), the Fiji Development 
Bank (FDB), and the status of capital market development.   
(xii)  With the assistance of the other consultants, assess the disparities between rural 
and  outer  islands  and  urban  incomes,  employment,  and  other  economic 
opportunities, and comment on policies to promote development in rural areas 
and outer islands. 
(xiii)  Examine  and  analyze  the  possibilities  of  alterative  livelihood  for  people 
depending on the sugar sector, and suggest policy directions for the same.   
(xiv)  Comment on sectoral and thematic priorities for development partners in light of 
the new emphasis of the Government, as reflected in the various government 
documents including the Rebuilding Confidence for Stability and Growth for a 
Peaceful and Prosperous Fiji: 2003-2005.  
(xv)  Organize  workshops  and  seminars  involving  the  Government,  funding 
community, academicians, private business, and civil-society groups to seek the 
views  of  all  stakeholders.  Lead  team  presentations  in  major  workshops  and 
seminars, and briefing of senior officials and ministers. 
(xvi)  Coordinate  and  integrate  the  findings  and  recommendations  of  all  sector 
specialists.  In  consultation  with  the  Government  and  ADB,  prepare  the  Fiji 
Islands  PIER  according  to  ADB’s  specifications,  including  clear  chapter-by-
chapter executive summaries. 
 
3.  The team leader will be responsible for the completion of all analyses and report 
writing, and for the overall quality of the report. 
 
B.  Private Sector Development Economist (1 person-month) 
 
4.  The TOR of the economist will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  Prepare a brief review of reports and documents, including recent surveys and 
statistics, of private sector development, public enterprises, and manufacturing 
and industry in the country. In these areas, review trends in growth, ownership 
and investment patterns, efficiency of operations, and their economic and social 
implications.  
(ii)  Review and analyze in detail the possibilities of public-private partnerships.  
(iii)  Review and analyze the private sector environment, tax incentives, industrial 
relations, legal and regulatory framework including investment laws, competitive 
mechanisms,  property  rights  and  insolvency  laws,  and  investment  approval 
process  related  to  domestic  and  foreign  investments.  Review  the  existing 
policies, and suggest improvements.

10  Appendix 3 
(iv)  Review and analyze developments in public and private investments, especially 
examine the factors and reasons for the decline in private investment and the low 
return on public investment.  
(v)  Review and analyze the manufacturing and industrial sector and its development 
in the country including informal micro- and small-scale enterprises, and make 
concrete suggestions about the newly created National Center for Small and 
Micro Enterprise Development. 
(vi)  Assess  the  status  and  prospects  of  development  of  information  and 
communication technology (ICT) and suggest policy options.  
(vii)  Prepare  and  complete  relevant  chapters  of  the  PIER.  Prepare  an  executive 
summary  for  each  chapter  and  help  the  team  leader  consolidate  the  final 
document after soliciting reviews and comments. 
 
C.  Infrastructure Economist (1 person-month) 
 
5.  The TOR of the economist will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  Prepare a brief review of reports and documents, including recent surveys and 
statistics, of infrastructure, transport, and utilities in the country. In these areas, 
review  trends  in  growth,  ownership  and  investment  patterns,  efficiency  of 
operations, and their economic and social implications. Analyze their impact on 
productive activities such as agriculture production, tourism, fishing, industrial 
and mining activities, etc., particularly in the remote areas and outer islands. 
(ii)  Review and analyze in detail the possibilities of public-private partnerships in the 
infrastructure,  utilities,  and  transport  sector.  Examine  the  options,  including 
management contracts, build operate and transfer (BOT) and its variant, and 
other possible modes of achieving the same.  
(iii)  Evaluate and comment on the operation and effectiveness of the Government’s 
infrastructure development and maintenance policies and programs, including 
private sector participation, and the regulatory framework. 
(iv)  Analyze the infrastructure and transport systems and their maintenance, cost 
recovery, and cross subsidies; identify constraints; and suggest policy options for 
their  sustainable  development.  In  particular,  assess  the  performance  and 
medium-term requirements of, and suggest reforms for (a) the transport sector 
(road, shipping, and air), (b) the power sector, including electrification in the rural 
areas, (c) telecommunications, (d) water supply, and (e) building of infrastructure 
in the outer islands.  
(v)  Identify the constraints on production and tourism, which result from inadequate 
infrastructure. Assess the impact of additional transportation costs, which result 
from  the  Fiji  Islands'  remoteness,  on  economic  growth,  cost  of  living,  and 
economic vulnerability. 
(vi)  Prepare  and  complete  relevant  chapters  of  the  PIER.  Prepare  an  executive 
summary  for  each  chapter  and  help  the  team  leader  consolidate  the  final 
document after soliciting reviews and comments. 
 
D.  Agriculture and Resource Economist (1.5 person-months)  
 
6.  The TOR of the economist will include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare a brief review of reports and documents, including recent surveys and 
statistics of agriculture, fisheries, forestry, mining, and tourism. Review trends in

Appendix 3  11 
agriculture,  fisheries,  forestry,  mining,  and  tourism  in  terms  of  subsistence 
production  (where  applicable),  cash  activities,  investment  environment, 
bottlenecks to growth, development potential, and export opportunities. Highlight 
the  constraints  on  and  options  for  the  development  of  agriculture,  fisheries, 
forestry, mining, and tourism, focusing on policy, environmental sustainability, 
employment creation, and poverty reduction. 
(ii)  Analyze the development options and related strategies for policy, infrastructure, 
incentives,  marketing,  processing  and  quarantine  issues  (as  applicable), 
research, and service improvements for catalyzing private sector development in 
agriculture, fisheries, forestry, mining, and tourism. 
(iii)  Review and analyze the structure of the sugar industry and strategies for its 
restructuring.  Examine  the  social  and  economic  costs  of  restructuring  and 
suggest strategies for mitigating potentially disrupting effects.  
(iv)  With the assistance of the team leader and the private sector and infrastructure 
economist,  assess  the  development  and  suggest  policy  options  for  the 
development of rural markets and adequate availability of rural credit.  
(v)  Examine and review all issues related to the standing mahogany crop, including 
its management and how to obtain the best economic return through processing 
and value addition.  
(vi)  Prepare sector road maps in accordance of ADB requirements for fisheries and 
tourism. The summary of these should be reflected in the PIER.  
(vii)  Prepare relevant PIER chapters that incorporate a sector analysis of agriculture, 
fisheries, forestry, and tourism. Prepare an executive summary for each sector. 
Assist the team leader to consolidate the final PIER and solicit reviews and 
comments. 
 
E.  Social Sector and Environment Specialist (1.25 person-months) 
 
7.  The TOR of the specialist will include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare a brief review of reports and documents, including recent surveys and 
statistics, related to the social sectors (health, education, gender and youth, and 
social protection) and the environment. Review and analyze the trends of social 
and environmental indicators to identify weaknesses and suggest policy options. 
(ii)  Analyze and comment on population trends, employment opportunities for the 
new entrants in the labor force, and out-migration of skilled labor. Assess their 
impact on human resource availability and on the country’s future competitive 
edge and economic growth. 
(iii)  Examine  current  educational  policies,  in  particular  vocational  and  technical 
education, and suggest options.  
(iv)  Examine current health policies, in particular primary health care and preventive 
medicine,  and  suggest  options.  With  the  assistance  of  the  macroeconomist, 
comment  on  the  possibilities  and  options  of  introducing  medical  insurance 
schemes in the country.  
(v)  Review and analyze (a) the service delivery systems, particularly in rural areas; 
(b) government expenditure on social sectors; (c) the cost recovery aspects; and 
(d) the role of the private sector in social sector activities. Assess the Fiji Islands’ 
resource requirements to meet these needs effectively and suggest cost effective 
options.  
(vi)  Examine the growing incidence of poverty and trends in equality of access to 
social  services  (health  care,  education,  etc.)  particularly  for  the  poor  and

residents of remote areas. Review and analyze the results of the new urban 
household income and expenditure survey to draw priority areas and suggest 
policy options.  
(vii)  Analyze social protection mechanisms, social safety net programs, and their 
effectiveness. Assess gender disparities in economic and social opportunities. 
(viii)  Review and analyze the housing sector, particularly in the rural areas, outer 
islands, and slum and squatter settlements, assess the financing required for 
these, and suggest how to augment available finances to fill the gap.  
(viii)  Review  and  analyze  environmental  issues;  their  management,  legal,  and 
regulatory framework; enforcement of standards within the country; solid waste 
management;  sanitation;  and  the  impact  of  global  climate  change  and 
greenhouse gas emission on the country.   
(ix)  Prepare  and  complete  relevant  chapters  of  the  PIER.  Prepare  an  executive 
summary and help the team leader consolidate the final document after soliciting 
reviews and comments. 
 
F.  Reporting Requirements 
 
8.  The team leader will submit in to the Government and ADB the following reports: 
 
(i)  inception report, within 1 week of the start of services, to contain the detailed 
work plan and the draft outline of the PIER; 
(ii)  fortnightly reports, every 2 weeks after the inception report during the field 
work, to describe the progress of TA implementation and summarize the findings; 
(iii)  draft final reports, within 2 weeks of the end of field work, to include the draft 
final PIER and an overall summary report of the TA; and 
(iv)  a final report, 2 weeks after the receipt of comments from the Government and 
ADB on the draft PIER, incorporating comments and other revisions. 
 
9.  Members of the team of consultants will provide the team leader reports and information
